item.title: Screencasting
item.description:
Checklist

Before recording always make sure...

  • You've got the links you want to view open in tabs in a browser window
  • You've got headphones / some kind of microphone to record your voice
    • You can use internal microphones but the quality on them is pretty bad so try to use a headset / earbuds if you have them
  • You've authorized whatever it is to record your voice and test that audio is working!
    • I fell victim to this many times early on

Next you'll need to pick a screen casting tool to do the recording. I recommend one of the following.

Zoom (Free)

Link : https://cmm.psu.edu/zoom/

Penn state labs come with zoom installed. You can also install this on your personal device and should be able to do recordings from it. I recommend finding a quite place that you can bring headphones since you'll have to do voice over describing what's on screen and explaining it to others.

Screencastify (Free, ad based with paid option)

Link : https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/screencastify-screen-vide/mmeijimgabbpbgpdklnllpncmdofkcpn?hl=en

I just found this recently, it's a browser plugin for Chrome. If you're O.K. with the permissions that it requires , it's a very easy to use way of generating a screencast.

Snagit (Paid)

Link :  https://www.techsmith.com/snagit-pricing.html

I use Snagit personally for all of my screen casting that I do. It is $30 but comes with some basic ways of doing quick editing and image mock up as well. It's not required that you use Snagit by any means, just saying what I've had positive experiences with previously.

Others

If you find others that you like feel free to share them with the class. The purpose of this class is not to get into high end video editing so beware that it is expected you'll generate videos each week. The content of the video is what matters, not fancy intros or well cut jumps or anything like that. Being able to fluidly communicate about a technical concept and teach others about how to use it and what it is.

item.title: Lab 2 - Git / Github / Contribution
item.description:
September 4th, 2019 - Lab 2

We've talked about git for version control and explored Github a bit and how teams work together using the platform. Now let's dig in!

Basic example / Getting started

  1. Create a GitHub account
  2. Fork this repo by going to this link and clicking "Fork" in the top right
  3. Read along in the document and complete the tasks asked of you by navigating to the README.md file and hitting edit.
  4. We'll work through this in class and I'll mix between showing things interactively done between specific people as well as roaming around to answer questions
  5. After you make the updates requested in the document, issue a "Pull Request" back against the source (my repo)
  6. Fill out the details indicating what you changed and we'll talk through it in class how this is the building block for all web based development collaborations

Let's start contributing to an open source project!

Let's start contributing to our first open source project! I've left a few issues in my own projects so that we can see the full project development life cycle at play here. Don't worry, these are minor documentation and spelling issues which while seeming minor, are a HUGE deal to developers and project managers as far as community involvement.

EVERYONE (me included) start out getting into a development community by updating documentation, making sure acronyms made sense and fixing links and typos. It's the best way to get into a software community is to fix things around the edges and ensure that you can effectively communicate with people in the project. It also helps prove they are human.

  1. Select one of the issues from this list of issues
  2. Read the description of what needs fixed, ask questions if you need clarification, and comment in the thread indicating that you plan on working on it.
  3. Hit FORK on the repo, fix the issue and submit a pull request.

item.title: Lab 1 - Building your digital identity
item.description:
August 28th, 2019 - Lab 1 / first class

This is a warm up lab that will help set the stage for the platforms we'll use for the rest of the semester.

  1. Create a Slack account and join two slack channels
    • IST 402 - Slack Invite
      • We'll use this as the primary working space / link sharing / communication space for the course
    • ELMS: Learning Network - Slack Invite
      • Me and my band of nuts are available to you. If you want to get more involved in this space beyond what we'll experience in class or have questions about the education or web industry, the door is always open
      • There's developers and educational professionals from multiple universities there, IST and otherwise.
  2. Think up a brand / identity / persona for your online identity as an IT professional
    • What does your brand feel like?
      • Great Explainer? Hero's Journey? Future CIO?
    • Pick a name that you can attempt to use across "all platforms"
      • Domain name, Github, Twitter, LinkedIn, YouTube
    • Note: You MAY want to divorce this from your real persona / personal accounts. Everyone does it differently in industry; many merge, there are risks associated with that. I fragment on YouTube  but generally keep all mine unified.
    • Because we haven't started a blog yet (but let's get in the swing of doing a write up and a video), write up a paragraph describing your brand and post it to the IST 402 Slack in the  #lab-1-brand-management channel
  3. Register this account on Github, Twitter, LinkedIn, YouTube
    • Be sure to set the username to be the same across them
  4. Create a Playlist on YouTube called "Clarissa explains it all", replacing Clarissa with your persona
  5. Create a screencast that's 2 - 5 minutes long that includes the following:
    • Pick a screencasting solution from the Screencasting resources area
    • introducing your channel from a technology professional context
    • Showing your favorite tech blog / anything you've read and enjoy learning from online currently. Talk about an article on the blog while it's being shown in order to practice the explainer concept.
    • End with what piece of technology you'd like to learn more about how it works from the topics in the survey
  6. Post a link to this video on your social accounts (Twitter / LinkedIn) with some setup to try and draw people to it using 3 hashtags
  7. On Twitter: Make sure you @EdTechJoker & @btopro so we can aggregate and review posts more easily.
    1. You can also use the IST402 Slack directly  and post to the channel named #lab-1-brand-management channel instead of tweeting it if you'd prefer.

item.title: Goals.. for you!
item.description:
My primary goal for you is to learn new things about modern web technologies while getting hands on with them. More specifically...

  • Learning not just what a technology is but...
    • Who's using it, what industries, what web services
    • Getting hands on and implementing it small scale
    • Being able to better communicate purpose and ideas around it
  • Building a digital footprint of YOU, the IT worker / manager / developer / whatever your path, just that it's out there!
    • Creating a YouTube channel of explainer videos about the topics discussed in class
    • Creating a Blog about these same topics
    • Creating social coder accounts and connecting them all together (like Github, TravisCI, Stackblitz, CodePen, Glitch, IFTTT, etc)
  • Learn about all levels of "the stack" in order to better empathize with those working in different levels of the stack from you (or people you'll one day manage)
  • Have a website on the internet that you control and have a window into how all aspects of it function.
  • Take hand written tests and use platforms and technologies that no employer on earth will care about once you graduate

Ok.. maybe not that last one but the rest are legit.

item.title: After class reflection
item.description:
All assignments are setup as labs and you'll be starting into them at the end of class. Once finished with the lab, you'll demonstrate you've done the work by reflecting on it in the form of a written response as well as a video response. Then we'll review some of the responses at the start of the next class. Scroll down to read both things that you are expected to complete each week as part of reflection on the topic of the lab. Yes I enjoy bold text.

Written response

To each technology, I'd like you to write a short blog post that reads like a one-page white paper about the technology at hand. Try to keep it to around 500 words but thoroughness is more important then "did I make the paper long enough".

As long as it answers questions like the following:

  • What is it and why does it exist
  • What industries use it / who are players that popularize it?
  • What alternatives exist to it?
  • Links / Resources for people who want to learn more about it
  • What you struggled with in using it?
  • What you liked most about using it?

Video response

Explainer videos are great, especially for people on the go via podcasts or who are looking to get a refresher on a topic before a meeting. Make a 3-5 minute screencast that sets up what the topic is, and runs through some brief examples of it. This is open to interpretation but you are trying to explain to others why this topic is valuable and when they'd use it.

  • Say quickly who you are
  • Explain in 30 seconds what the topic is, who's using it or why it's useful
  • Talk about the topic while showing a demo of it or place you found most useful to learn
  • Show links to resources where you can learn more about it
  • Awesome sign off phrase to remember you by

Here are a few examples of the kind of formality that is expected (flip on screencast software, record screen, talk). Part of the video reflection is to get more comfortable with speaking about technical concepts and to improve your ability to rationalize what your doing. I don't use a script (ever) for my videos but that's up to you.

item.title: Class time together
item.description:
We're going to strive for this general flow to each week of the semester. A few specific topics will deviate and we may have some guest speakers, but generally this is what class will look like together

  • Capability / skill / technology of the day with quick discussion of what people think that's for, or places they've heard of it previously
  • A brief lecture (25 - 30 min) about the skill, who uses it, and how it's put into practice. This is taking the concept into the theory realm.
  • Screw theory, we're only going to learn by getting our hands dirty! We'll take a quick break to prep the keyboards. (10 min for questions, 5 min break)
  • Next we'll all follow along doing a very basic example of the skill / a warm up activity. This might be running commands in a terminal or hooking up a new IFTTT command to Github via the UI. Something that's all of us following along and doing it together, stopping to answer any questions along the way.
  • The rest of the time from here is open lab. We'll have a lab each week with a few options for experiencing and implementing the skill in practice.
  • What ever you don't get done in class is to be completed after class but we'll always start on the work together in case there are issues.

item.title: Building your digital identity
item.description:
No one knows who you are if you're not effectively communicating. I recall a colleague several years ago getting pissed that I was invited to speak some place. "It's like no one knows I exist or appreciates what I know". He was absolutely just as or more tallented than I was... what was the difference?

  • I've blogged openly about tech and life since 2008
  • I've got hundreds of YouTube videos ranging from "Hey look at this thing" to "let's learn about..." to "We're going to burn down this space"
  • I've got unified social media accounts that signal boost content from the other spaces

As a result of having a unified social media front and regular presence on blogs / YouTube, I've gotten to speak nationally on a regular basis the last ten years. Every recorded association of a brand or event to you personally is another form of signal boosting.

Theory

A theory I learned about in Grad school that stuck with me the most is called Actor Network Theory (ANT). ANT can be argued as to if it's actually a theory, but the TLDR; is that all things influence each other.

For information sciences though, it's saying that anything created influences anything else created. This is particularly potent in the digital space when we can create a logo, brand, business, website, identity, or platform seemingly out of thin air. If I post on YouTube, I'm not just broadcasting there and increasing my brand recognition in that space. It's aggregated to blogs, it shows up in Google and Bing search results. Its lifted for replication on Russian botnet sites.

All of this, amplifies your voice and reach far beyond you speaking in public (again, duh). But if you recognize this, you can also weaponize it to your advantage (or be a Russian troll bot online and corrupt other countries cultures, I mean tomatoe tomatto). Through intentionality, we can increase our profile as technology professionals and begin to build a portfolio that anyone can stumble on (or seek out intentionally) to increase their knowledge.

item.title: Questions driven teaching
item.description:
In all the technologies and skillsets we'll explore in this course, I want you to approach them with the same questions that I have explored in my career. These simple questions will help you decipher what's going to get you the furthest for the longest.

Technological sustainability is not easy; both in remaining relevant by sustaining your own skills as well as the sustained use of any solution by anyone or their organization.

What problem does this solve?

Who built this?

Where is this being used?

How can I go about using it?

Why do people use this over alternatives? (and what are the top 3 alternatives)

With each problem / solution space we look at in this course we're going to look at it through the lens of these questions.

item.title: Topic overview
item.description:
ARE YOU READY!?

Are you ready to hit power level 9000!? Then read through this lesson plan to be a super saiyan.

Topic / semester outline

Here's the proposed topics I've come up with to start. We may deviate from here as far as timing or how long we spend on different ones.

  • Week 1 - Establishing an online identity as an IT Professional (Vlogger)
    • Treating ourselves as brands, we will establish accounts and begin to setup the foundation for submission of assignments throughout the semester
  • Week 2 – Git / Github / Contribution (All roles)
    • Collaborative participation on Github, understanding concepts of Git / version control and how teams leverage this technology for code and non-code projects
  • Week 3 – Creating a website + server (Sys admin)
    • We’ll use this for a blog and other experiments throughout the semester but we’ll mostly demystify the process
  • Week 4 – Terminal and Command line basics (Sys admin)
    • Step by step through the basic commands that system developers use to make everything work
  • Week 5 - HTML / CSS / JavaScript (Front end)
    • The big three powering most of what you use today, a primer for reverse engineering. We’ll use codepen to demonstrate how you can extend concepts of github into other realms
  • Week 6 - Package management & Reuse (Front end)
    • NPM / Composer and how we stand on the shoulders of giants
  • Week 7 - Web components & Progressive Web Apps (Front end)
    • HTML on steroids and the future of all application development, web or otherwise
    • We’ll look at why this is transformative for application development and why all teams should be exploring it from an efficiency perspective. We’ll also experiment with a powerful new platform called Stackblitz to demonstrate the power of Package management + compartmentalized HTML
  • Week 8 – Mid-term
    • We’ll have a mid-term based on the technologies and skills covered the 1st  half
    • There will be no lab this week.
    • Come to class, take the exam and then you're free to leave or use the open lab time for catching up on past labs.
  • Week 9 - Open source communities (All roles)
    • We’ll review governance within open source communities, understand the difference between licenses, learn how different structures operate (including Open vs Closed), see how to identify healthy vs stagnated open source communities, and learn when people fallback to proprietary technologies.
  • Week 10 - Content management systems (All roles)
    • A window into Drupal, WordPress, GravCMS, HAXcms to understand how they work, limitations, why they are popular, how their communities operate
  • Week 11 – Accessibility (Front end / Developer)
    • What is it, why is it important, who benefits, how do we test for it?
  • Week 12 - User experience (Front end / Designer)
    • Persona creation and testing using real world applications
  • Week 13 - Server Virtualization technologies (DevOps)
    • Vagrant and Docker have changed the web forever, we’ll explore these and surrounding applications and learn why they are so powerful
  • Week 14 – Thanksgiving Break
    • Eat items.
  • Week 15-16 Educational Technology, Open Education Resources (Edtech)
    • We’ll look at the courses we’re taking and its usage of technology, where this technology is usable, where it’s not. Where accessibility can be improved or accounted for.
    • We’ll look at OER / open course technology movements from philosophical, societal and technological perspectives.
    • We’ll audit systems the instructor works on / has worked on to identify gaps in existing technologies, critique what’s available and ideate about how technologies discussed throughout the class can be leveraged
    • These labs will be combined into a single submission with 10% of the grade. Lab time will be spent learning about the context and having access to instructors to help while exploring the topic.

item.title: About the instructor (boring)
item.description:
This is the approved, boring version of who I am. If you found this page, bring it up in class and you'll be rewarded with a crisp high five.

My name is Bryan Ollendyke and I've been living working at Penn State since 2007. I did my undergrad in IST and was able to get a job working in the College of Arts & Architecture's online learning unit (now called Office of Digital Learning).

In 2015 I completed my MS by studying the spread of an open source platform called Drupal. The theory I reasoned from my thesis is an effect I call Information Altruism -- Meaning that it isn't open source software that impacts institutions but the free giving away of knowledge about how to use it  which does.

Open source lays the ground work, but it still requires knowledge workers to pick up those raw minerals and make rails of them for organizations to ride on.

I am in the rare position of getting to teach you leveraging tools which I and my team have built. This content is written in a platform called HAXcms which we are actively building. I'm also the project lead on a project called ELMS: Learning Network.

Since starting at Penn State, I would say 99.5% of every hour of every day I work is contributed directly back to open code and documentation. I've contributed hundreds of modules for Drupal, dozens of themes and installation profiles, millions of lines of code liberated from the ownership of anyone or anywhere.

In the last two years, our team has released north of 400 reusable design assets called Web components. These modules and design assets power thousands of websites and help empower people we'll never know to better express themselves online, whether for instructional content or otherwise.

I'm a self described Developer Activist in that I don't think open source can change society: I know it can and does constantly. It's why I still work in academia - to try and open source as much of the application stack associated with teaching and learning in order to provide both better options as well as lower costs.

item.title: Git / Github / Contribution
item.description:
Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency.

Git provides a command line interface or CLI that allows developers to track changes in the code they are writing. Some basic commands in git are as follows

All git is doing, is keeping track of a simple record that indicates what a line number WAS and what it should be now. Here's an example from the HAXcms Readme file

In this example, we can see that lines 18 and 19 in the file called README.md were changed. The left in red is what it was. The right in green is what it became. This visualization is provided by Github, where I manage the vast majority of my projects.

Github is a popular space for developers in and out of open source software communities to collaborate. Microsoft recently purchased Github but the platform has been popular with developers of open source projects for over a decade prior.

Github has gained popularity in part because

  • Git as a version control system has largely won the popularity contest
  • They allow you to use the platform for free so long as what you do is open source
  • Private repos then allow companies to align their open contribution strategy with their internal development workflows
  • Github's social networking aspects around issue queues, following, forking and staring repos have all helped improve the social aspect of software development online
  • Github is adding capabilities to make code contributions without needing to understand everything that goes into making the contribution. Capabilities like clicking edit on the website, making a change in the browser and typing the commit name, then it automatically saving the change or creating a "Pull Request" for whoever owns the file
  • All of these reasons are why developers and non-developers  are joining Github to do a lot of open source contribution.
  • Lots of other services and "apps" are starting to integrate with Github as a platform and as a login system

There is an open source variation of GitHub called GitLab. Gitlab is used by the university to share code internally (like WebAccess, security related code), automate workflows and increase collaboration between organizations.

For the purposes of this class we're going to focus on Github as it will provide the most visibility for you and what you are showcasing as being able to do.

item.title: Welcome
item.description:
IST 402: Emerging Technologies

My name is Bryan Ollendyke, and welcome to IST 402: Emerging Tech!

I'm excited to expose you to the ideas and technologies I wish I had been exposed to when I was in IST. I graduated from IST in 2006 (and again in 2015), and while I took some programming focused courses in undergrad, it wasn't until I starting working on projects for the university that I had to learn on the job all aspects of real software development.

I am a unicorn in the industry. A unicorn is often known as a "Full Stack Developer". It's a thing that "doesn't exist" or isn't to be sought after. The market tends to force hyper specialization, front end, back end, sys ops, dev ops, css / designer as opposed to one person that can touch all aspects of the application. I've been collecting a mix of unicorns through my work at the university and would love to share our experiences with you and expose you to technologies we work on every day.

I love open source software, hockey, web technologies, Penn State, and meme's.... cause obviously. I present regularly at events around the country on web components, educational technology, NGDLE, and Drupal / PHP at both technical events and educator centric ones.

I walk between worlds and hope to provide you with a unique perspective in the process!

Course description

We're going to learn about and participate in open source software communities. We're going to use github to do this. We're going to make YouTube channels full of knowledge that you've assembled in this course, create social media posts promoting it and other projects you'll work on, and generally give you a sense of the skills required to get involved in start up culture.

We'll cover human things like workflow management, user experience, community building and accessibility.

We'll get into amazing web services like Stackblitz.io, CloudFlare, DigitalOcean, Github, IFTTT, TravisCI, Slack, talk about how they work, play with them, and blog about using them.

We'll cover technical concepts like Web components, version control (git), Content managment systems, "flat file" systems.

We'll get hands on and write markdown, yaml, json, web components (HTML/CSS/JS).

We'll "build servers" and make our own website to understand how all that works.

We'll generally remove the magic that divides consumers from producers in the digital realm and get you a step closer being involved in a start up.

The vast majority of your work will be done out in the open to help you build an identity as an IT professional and someone that has the right accounts and is active with them come interview time or where ever you find yourself after this place.

My goals for this course are to get you more comfortable with these tools, build your online personal / brand, and hopefully get you commits to real world open source projects.

(Boring) "Blue Book" description from {terrible } LionPath

Start up? Let's Tool up!

The "Start up" culture is a world that lives by "move fast and break things". But how do you get into the start up scene? Or more importantly, what do you need to know in order to attract offers, and get your resume to stand out in a world where thousands of "IT workers" will graduate along side you.

You'll contribute to a large Penn State lead Open Source software project while building your digital identity as an IT professional on your journey to 1337 (elite). You'll improve online education while using things like version control (git), docker, web components, terminal, servers, screencasting and writing technical documentation.

You'll work with platforms like Github, Digital Ocean, HAXcms, IFTTT, Slack, Travis CI and YouTube. Prior programming knowledge is beneficial but understanding of technical concepts is more important.

(Fun) Reality description

This
